choices.text: Intracranial calcification
Chorioretinitis
Convulsions
Cardiac abnormalities

questions.text: Triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardiac abnormalities

 

Option D.

 

 

The triad of congenital toxoplasmosis consists of:

 

  • Transmission of disease takes place through transplacental route.
  • The mother is often symptom-free or has only mild constitutional manifestations.
  • The severity of fetal involvement is tends to be more severe in early pregnancy, when fetal death may result.
  • Active disease – necrotic granulomatous retinochoroiditis involving macular region.
  • Inactive disease – bilateral healed punched out pigmented chorioretinal scars in macula.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intracranial Calcification: Periventricular calcification is a common finding in congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Option B. Chorioretinitis: Chorioretinitis is an inflammation of the choroid and retina of the eye. In congenital toxoplasmosis, it can lead to visual impairment or blindness. It is one of the most common and long-lasting consequences of this infection.

 

Option C. Convulsions: Convulsions or seizures can occur as a result of the central nervous system involvement in congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and convulsions, with cardiac abnormalities not being a typical component of this triad.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Behçet disease
Fuchs uveitis syndrome
HLA B27 associated anterior uveitis
Traumatic uveitis

questions.text: Mobile hypopyon is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Behçet disease

 

Option A:

 

  • Mobility of hypopyon depends on its fibrin content.
  • High fibrin content – immobile hypopyon
  • Low fibrin content – hypopyon shifts according to the patient’s head position. This is seen in Behcet disease.
  • Immobile hypopyon is common in HLAB27-associated AAU.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fuchs Uveitis Syndrome: Fuchs Uveitis Syndrome is a chronic, typically unilateral uveitis. It is characterized by minimal or no pain and low-grade inflammation. Hypopyon is not a typical feature of this condition.

 

Option C. HLA B27 Associated Anterior Uveitis: HLA B27 associated uveitis can be acute and intense and immobile hypopyon. HLA B27 uveitis tends to present with acute, painful red eye and significant photophobia.

 

Option D. Traumatic Uveitis: Traumatic uveitis can follow an injury to the eye. While hypopyon can occur in traumatic uveitis, it's more commonly associated with infectious complications post-trauma rather than being directly mobile.

 

Educational objective:

 

Immobile hypopyon is seen in Behcets Disease.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Sarcoidosis
Periphlebitis retinae
Behçet disease
Acute retinal necrosis

questions.text: Identify.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

Option A:

 

  • In the given fundus picture, there is presence of multiple yellowish white perivenous exudates with sheathing – referred to as ‘candle wax drippings’ (‘en taches de bougie’).
  • This is typical of severe sarcoid periphlebitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Periphlebitis Retinae: Periphlebitis retinae is an inflammatory condition affecting the retinal veins, often seen in association with systemic diseases like tuberculosis presenting with multiple peripheral branch retinal vein occlusions. This is also known as Eales disease.

 

 

Option C. Behçet Disease: Behçet disease is a systemic vasculitis that can involve the retina, causing recurrent uveitis and vasculitis, potentially leading to complications like retinal hemorrhage and vision loss.

 

 

Option D. Acute Retinal Necrosis: Acute retinal necrosis is a rare but severe viral infection of the retina, usually caused by herpes viruses, characterized by rapid progression of retinal necrosis, uveitis, and can lead to retinal detachment and severe vision loss. It starts in retinal periphery and spreads centripetally.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical picture of Candle wax dripping is suggestive of sarcoidosis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: A29
B5
DR4
B27

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with low back ache was referred for ophthalmic consult in view of acute red eye. The patient was advised HLA typing. What is the likely HLA positivity to expect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B27

 

Option D:

 

  • A young male patient with complaints of low backache and features of acute anterior uveitis raises a suspicion of Ankylosing spondylitis. The HLA associated with AS is HLA B27.
  • HLA type Associated disease

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A29: HLA-A29 is strongly associated with Birdshot chorioretinopathy, a rare form of posterior uveitis, not primarily linked with low backache.

 

Option B. B5: HLA-B5 has been linked to Behçet's disease, which can cause uveitis, but it is not typically associated with isolated low backache.

 

Option C. DR4: HLA-DR4 is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis and some other autoimmune conditions, but it's not the primary HLA type associated with ankylosing spondylitis and uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with low backache and acute red eye, HLA-B27 positivity is the most likely.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Toxoplasmosis
Sarcoidosis
Behcets disease
Sympathetic ophthalmitis

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

Option A.

 

  • The given fundus picture is characterized by severe vitreous haze and presence of a yellowish white lesion – s/o active retinochoroiditis (HEADLIGHT IN THE FOG APPEARANCE) seen in Toxoplasmosis.

  • Toxoplasmosis is a form of parasitic uveitis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

  • It is the most common identifiable cause for focal retinitis, which typically causes inflammation adjacent to a chorioretinal scar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: In sarcoidosis, ocular involvement can include anterior or posterior uveitis, with possible formation of granulomas.

 

Option C. Behcet’s Disease: Behcet’s disease is a systemic vasculitis that can involve the eyes, often presenting as recurrent episodes of uveitis.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Ophthalmia: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral, granulomatous panuveitis that typically occurs after trauma to one eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vitreous haze and presence of a yellowish white lesion – s/o active retinochoroiditis (HEADLIGHT IN THE FOG APPEARANCE) seen in Toxoplasmosis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Chest radiograph
Serum ACE
Mantoux test
X-ray SI joint

questions.text: A 35-year-old software engineer, presents with recurrent anterior uveitis, experiencing episodic eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity lasting about a week each time. What is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X-Ray SI joint

 

Option D.

 

  • Recurrent acute anterior uveitis (non-granulomatous) is usually suspected to be associated with Ankylosing spondylitis.
  • It is the most common ocular association which occurs in about 25% of patients with AS, affecting 1 eye at a time.
  • An X-Ray of SI joint is to be advised to see evidence of sacroiliitis, a feature of AS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chest Radiograph: A chest X-ray is useful in the evaluation of sarcoidosis, a systemic condition that can present with uveitis. However, the episodic nature of uveitis in a young adult is less typical of sarcoidosis.

 

Option B. Serum ACE (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme): Elevated serum ACE levels can be seen in sarcoidosis. While this could be considered if sarcoidosis is suspected, the clinical presentation here is more suggestive of a spondyloarthropathy.

 

Option C. Mantoux Test: The Mantoux test (tuberculin skin test) is used to screen for tuberculosis (TB). While TB can cause uveitis, the recurrent episodic anterior uveitis in a young adult is less indicative of TB-associated uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young adult presenting with recurrent episodes of anterior uveitis, an X-ray of the sacroiliac joint is an appropriate initial investigation to rule out an underlying spondyloarthropathy, such as ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Usher’s syndrome
Behcet’s disease
VKH
Fuchs uveitis syndrome

questions.text: A 28-year-old female visits an ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision, congestion and pain in both eyes. She also gives history of increased sensitivity to light and frequent headaches. There is no history of ocular trauma. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes bilateral uveitis. On asking further, she says she has noticed patches of white hair on her scalp (poliosis), depigmented spots on her face and hands and difficulty in hearing in the past few months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VKH

 

Option C.

 

  • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome is an idiopathic autoimmune condition with multisystem involvement.
  • It causes inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues such as the uvea, ear and meninges.
  • HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4 association is noted.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Usher syndrome: It includes retinitis pigmentosa and deafness.

 

Option B. Behçet disease: An idiopathic multisystem disease characterized by recurrent, non-granulomatous uveitis, aphthous ulceration, genital ulcerations and erythema multiforme. It is associated with HLA-B51 and B5.

 

Option D. Fuchs uveitis syndrome: a chronic non-granulomatous condition diagnosed at an average of 40 years of age. Gradual blurring due to cataract is a common presentation. Other signs include: heterochromia iridis, faint AC flare, absent posterior synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of the 28-year-old female patient, with symptoms of bilateral uveitis, poliosis (patches of white hair), depigmented spots on skin, and hearing difficulty, is highly suggestive of Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) disease.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Initiation of steroids is mandatory.
Excision of injured eye, irrespective of visual potential.
Atropine is indicated in all cases.
Immunomodulators are recommended in severe cases.

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of penetrating injury in the right eye presented with bilateral granulomatous panuveitis. All are true regarding treatment, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Excision of injured eye, irrespective of visual potential.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given condition is diagnostic of SYMPATHETIC OPHTHALMITIS.
  • It is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma.
  • Presentation in trauma induced cases is between 2 weeks and 3 months.

 

 

Management:

 

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Positive tuberculin skin test
Elevated serum lysozyme levels
Abnormal liver function test
Elevated serum ACE levels

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy was found to have granulomatous iridocyclitis on evaluation. All the following findings are associated with her diagnosis, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive tuberculin skin test

 

Option A:

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of SARCOIDOSIS.
  • Granulomatous anterior uveitis is the most common manifestation.
  • IWOS (International workshop on Ocular Sarcoidosis) formulated five investigations to be of significant value in the diagnosis of ocular sarcoidosis in patients having a compatible uveitis.

 

These include:

 

  1. Negative tuberculin skin test in a BCG-vaccinated patient or in a patient having had a positive tuberculin skin test previously.

A strongly positive reaction to one tuberculin unit makes a diagnosis of sarcoidosis highly unlikely.

  1. Elevated serum ACE levels and/or elevated serum lysozyme
  2. Chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
  3. Abnormal liver enzyme tests
  4. Chest CT scan in patients with a negative chest X-ray

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Elevated Serum Lysozyme Levels: Elevated serum lysozyme levels can be seen in sarcoidosis. Lysozyme is an enzyme found in granulocytes and macrophages, cells that are often involved in the granuloma formation characteristic of sarcoidosis.

 

Option C. Abnormal Liver Function Test: Abnormal liver function tests can occur in sarcoidosis, as the granulomas can affect the liver, leading to hepatic dysfunction.

 

Option D. Elevated Serum ACE Levels: Elevated serum Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) levels are often found in sarcoidosis. ACE is produced in higher quantities by the granulomas characteristic of this condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The finding not associated with sarcoidosis is A. Positive Tuberculin Skin Test.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Heerfordt’s disease
Acute retinal necrosis
VKH
Behcet’s syndrome

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient presented with symptoms of fever, malaise, and a painful swelling of the parotid gland. During the ocular evaluation, the patient was found to have granulomatous iridocyclitis. What is the possible etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heerfordt’s disease

 

Option A:

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of Uveoparotid fever or Heerfordt’s disease, a presentation of Sarcoidosis.
  • It is a bilateral condition.
  • Simultaneous involvement of the entire uveal tract and parotid gland is noted.
  • Common in 10 and 30 years of age.
  • Diplopia due to palsy of the ocular motor nerves or facial paralysis may occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Acute Retinal Necrosis: This is a viral infection of the retina, typically caused by the herpes virus family. It is characterized by retinal necrosis and not by parotid gland swelling or systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option C. Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) Disease: VKH is a multisystem disorder affecting melanocyte-containing organs, including the eyes, skin, and central nervous system. It presents with bilateral uveitis, often with neurological and skin manifestations, but does not typically involve the parotid gland.

 

Option D. Behçet's Syndrome: Behçet's disease is a systemic vasculitis that can cause uveitis, but it is also associated with oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and other systemic involvement. It does not typically involve the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heerfordt disease is a rare form of sarcoidosis and is characterized by a classic triad of symptoms: fever, parotid gland enlargement, and anterior uveitis, which can be granulomatous or Iridocyclitis.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition

choices.text: Bilateral uveitis
Presence of history of penetrating ocular trauma
Absence of other ocular disease
Neurological manifestations

questions.text: Amongst the Modified diagnostic criteria for the disease shown below, all are included except which one?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of history of penetrating ocular trauma

 

Option B:

 

The given fundus picture shows bilateral multifocal exudative retinal detachment with probable diagnosis being Vogt Koyanagi Harada syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bilateral Uveitis: Bilateral uveitis, particularly involving the posterior segment of the eye, is a key feature of VKH disease and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option C. Absence of Other Ocular Disease: The diagnosis of VKH disease requires the exclusion of other ocular diseases that could cause similar symptoms. Thus, the absence of other ocular disease is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option D. Neurological Manifestations: Neurological and auditory manifestations, such as meningismus, tinnitus, or vertigo, are part of the systemic manifestations associated with VKH disease and are included in its diagnostic criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of penetrating ocular trauma predisposes to sympathetic ophthalmia and is not a diagnostic criterion for Vogt Koyanagi Harada syndrome.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Anterior uveitis
Herpes zoster ophthalmicus
Retinal microangiopathy
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with an increased risk of CMV retinitis in patients with AIDS?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinal microangiopathy

 

Option C:

 

  • Retinal microangiopathy is the most frequent retinopathy in patients with AIDS.
  • It is associated with a declining CD4+ T cell count and higher plasma HIV-RNA levels.
  • It is a marker for increased cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis risk.
  • It occurs due to immune complex deposition, HIV infection of the retinal vascular endothelium and abnormalities in blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Uveitis: This is an inflammation of the front part of the uveal tract and does not have a direct association with an increased risk of CMV retinitis.

 

Option B. Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus: Caused by the varicella-zoster virus, this condition can occur in immunocompromised patients, including those with AIDS, but it is not a direct indicator of increased risk for CMV retinitis.

 

Option D. Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca: Also known as dry eye syndrome, it is a condition characterized by dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea. It is not specifically associated with an increased risk of CMV retinitis in AIDS patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinal microangiopathy is a condition often seen in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS. It involves changes in the small blood vessels of the retina and is indicative of a more compromised immune system. Patients with AIDS who have retinal microangiopathy are at a higher risk for opportunistic infections, including CMV retinitis, due to the advanced stage of their systemic.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Aqueous flare
Circumcorneal congestion
Pupillary myosis
Retrolental flare

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient with history of penetrating injury to left eye 1 month back, is at a risk of developing sympathetic ophthalmia. What is the first sign of this delayed hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retrolental flare

 

Option D:

 

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia:

 

  • Delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Takes place in the sound, fellow eye, about 4–8 weeks after penetrating wounds.
  • Though rare, the disease is potentially sight threatening.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aqueous Flare: Aqueous flare, caused by the presence of protein in the aqueous humor due to inflammation, is indeed one of the early signs of sympathetic ophthalmia. It indicates disruption of the blood-aqueous barrier, which is a hallmark of intraocular inflammation.

 

Option B. Circumcorneal Congestion: Circumcorneal congestion, or ciliary injection, is a sign of inflammation in the eye and often appears in various forms of uveitis, including sympathetic ophthalmia. However, it may not be the earliest sign compared to changes in the aqueous humor.

 

Option C. Pupillary Miosis: Pupillary miosis (constriction of the pupil) can occur in inflammatory conditions of the eye due to irritation of the iris, but it is not typically considered the first sign of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First ocular sign of sympathetic ophthalmia is retrolental flare.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Tuberculosis
Candidiasis
Toxoplasmosis
Histoplasmosis

questions.text: A child on routine examination was found to have the below described picture. What would you investigate for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

Option C:

 

  • The given picture is characterized by a well-circumscribed pigmented chorioretinal lesion (scar) in the inferotemporal quadrant.
  • This is probably a case of inactive congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • Other ophthalmic features: cataract, chorioretinitis, microphthalmos and optic atrophy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Ocular tuberculosis presents as granulomatous uveitis and multifocal or serpigenous choroiditis.

 

 

Option B: Candida – Candida presents as vitrous opacities.

 

 

Option D: Histoplasmosis – Ocular histoplasmosis presents midperipheral histo spots and choroidal neovascular membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A well punched out, well-circumscribed pigmented chorioretinal lesion is suggestive of ocular toxoplasma.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Evisceration scoop
Fixation forceps
Enucleation spoon
Strabismus scissors

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enucleation spoon

 

Option C:

 

Enucleation spoon

 

Spoon shaped instrument, with a central cleavage.

 

To engage the optic nerve during enucleation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Evisceration Scoop: An evisceration scoop is a specialized surgical instrument used to remove the contents of the eyeball, leaving the scleral shell and extraocular muscles intact, typically in procedures addressing severe eye infection or damage.

 

 

Option B. Fixation Forceps: Fixation forceps are precise gripping tools used in eye surgeries to stabilize and hold the eyeball, allowing for accurate and controlled surgical maneuvers.

 

 

Option D. Strabismus Scissors: Strabismus scissors are specialized scissors used in eye surgeries to correct strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), designed for cutting delicate eye muscles with precision and care.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enucleation scoop is identifiable from the groove for the optic nerve.

 

Ref: pg 603/ ophthalmic instruments & operative ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

choices.text: Pigment epithelium of retina
Sensory retina
Internal limiting membrane
Bruch’s membrane

questions.text: Layer of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body is the forward continuation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensory retina

 

Option B:

 

The layer of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body is a forward continuation of the sensory retina which stops at the ora serrata.

 

It continues anteriorly as the posterior pigmented epithelium of iris.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Pigmented Epithelium of Retina: The pigmented epithelium of the retina is a layer of cells that is essential for the function of the retina. It plays a role in the visual cycle and provides support to the photoreceptors.

 

Option C. Internal Limiting Membrane: The internal limiting membrane is the boundary between the retina and the vitreous body of the eye. It's the basement membrane of the Müller cells, which are a type of glial cell found in the retina.

 

Option D. Bruch’s Membrane: Bruch's membrane is part of the choroid, lying between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium. It's a thin, multi-layered structure that plays a role in supporting the retina and facilitating the exchange of nutrients and waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory retina continues forward as the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body.

 

Ref: pg 67 / anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA
